review_title: Nice Place But Don't Expect To Be Paid Well
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Very friendly colleagues. Most passionate about what they do. Nice office environment.
cons: I work in back-office administration. Think HR, IT, Finance, etc. During the best of times, annual pay increases are set to 3% if you're a top performer, and 2% if you're average. This has become increasingly problematic given inflation. Even more problematic is that the admin thinks we're idiots - but we know how to read a 990. We talk. And we know that the top-level staff gets annual raises way above 2%. Most staff put up with this because they come from disadvantage communities - either minorities or 50 years old or older. But it's wrong. Know in advance if you work here you will never get a real raise unless you are promoted. And promotions are extremely difficult to attain as I can tell from my colleagues who have been here over a decade in the same exact position.

job_title: Medical Assistant in New York, NY
pros: So far I have been employed as a medical assistant at Weill Cornell Medicine OB/GYN department for 6 months. Can be a hard job, but depending on which location in the city you work at, the doctors are very helpful. They are also very independent and are trusted when you have questions about a plan of care. Extremely knowledgable, caring, and fun. You have some doctors that are not as pleasing to work with, but the pay is good with opportunity for raises and bonuses. You get a moderately generous personal/vacation allowance, and the benefits are nice.
cons: A lot of mismanagement on the clinical side. 1. You only get your assignment/start time for the next day, the day before. Can be frustrating to plan things outside of work. 2. Their are only 2 nursing managers for the entire department, so when there are small problems that should be handles practice to practice, it can be difficult to find solutions. 3. You get floated :( after 6-months, you are expected to float to different locations to help. 4. Training is minimal and it will be hard to keep up without some prior experience.

job_title: Patient Research Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Pros were few and far between in this job. I met some great coworkers to share some of the trauma with.
cons: This is supposed to be an entry level job for research coordination. It is not. This is a sales position for the All of Us research program (please google). Leadership, training, and management are completely absent. Management is rarely seen, but when she is get ready for intimidation techniques; her super power was sending threatening emails. The turnover rate is extremely high. Within 6 months, 5-6 people quit or were fired. The most senior patient research coordinator had been there about 8 months. This left us with a team of all new employees, with no training, and no leadership. One example is the phlebotomy. We were "trained" by sticking each other with needles 3 times, and once successful, you could work on patients! All in all, this job is selling the All of Us research program, which is remarkably similar to a scam. Performance is fully based off of the call center. Making calls makes up 70-80% of the job, which you are never told until you begin. This was a waste of time in the scope of my career in clinical research. No relevant skills are learned or obtained, and there is very little opportunity for growth. Please be wary, there are other entry opportunities in the field. I know it's difficult, but you can find a suitable position that will help you grow as a CRC. There is so much more to share; i.e. working conditions, but i'll end there.

You have to figure out yourself the growth opportunities because at this role it just a job and unless this is a stepping stone for you, you will have to figure out what next steps you want to do. There is not a proper structure to help technicians grow which is unlike for graduate students and Post Docs.
cons: The HR immigration is really a mean person. All throughout Cornell it is just one HR employee that helps with the immigration process. The process was smooth but the interaction with her was literally the worst. Knowing she is HR I really dont know who to go to and complain about the way she talks, Also, she is an immigrant herself, and yet she is so mean. I was offered another role in the same company but that didnt go through due to immigration and instead of helping me out to grow she made it worse. I had to let go of the position. So more help for growth opportunities will be great.

review_title: Weill Cornell is the best organization ever! 6 years and counting...
job_title: Senior Medical Secretary in New York, NY
pros:
*Amazing benefits (Health, Dental, Vision insurance)
*Amazing Co-Workers and management
*Work/Life balance
*Growth Opportunities
*Weill Cornell becomes your 2nd family

If you work hard and do what you are supposed to do, your work will be recognized and acknowledged. I have been in Weill Cornell for over 6 years I started as a Patient Coordinator (2015) then got promoted to a Sr. Patient Coordinator (2017). I had a child and once you become a parent life changes happen out of the blue, Weill Cornell management were great in making accommodations with my work schedule. My supervisor even referred me to Lower Manhattan, which is just 25 min away from my home and this helped so much! The transfer was actually a promotion to Sr. Medical Secretary at LMH, the supervisor is also amazing and so understanding. Now I am currently going through some other life changes which I will need to relocate and being a single parent, it will be hard for me to look for child care in a place where you do not know anyone at all. With all the craziness going on with babysitters harming children you just don't trust anyone. So, I knew my best option would be to find a job where I can work from home, I applied to a few companies since I thought Weill Cornell did not have work from home opportunities. When I spoke to my supervisor and told her that I have been hired to work for another company she was devastated. And at that same moment without telling me she referred me to another supervisor whom did have work from home opportunities within Weill Cornell!!!! The job I had gotten hired for had horrible benefits in which were too expensive and I found myself having to apply to government health plans. So, This is something that I am so grateful for, now I can keep all my benefits and still work at Cornell. I took my time to write this review because I never thought that I was valued this much at work, and this will show prospective employees the true meaning and the outcomes of being hard working and dedicated to your job. Apart from that you form a strong bond with your co-workers, we are all a family here and I am grateful to be part of Weill Cornell!
cons:
*You have to deal with a lot of difficult patients.
*Heavy work load
***But it's all worth it!***

job_title: Research Technician in New York, NY
pros: Your experience may be decent depending on the lab you join
cons: I have been a victim of more wage theft here than at any other job I have had in my entire life. There has been no overtime "allowed" since COVID began. No one cares whether you stay or leave. HR and management are terrible. There is little opportunity for growth within the company, and salaries are on the low end of the scale compared to other institutions in the area. Feet were dragged in response to COVID. Because Cornell is affiliated with NYP and is thus an "essential" institution, a huge amount of non-essential in-person work was carried out throughout the worst of the pandemic, and nothing was done to compensate employees. Cornell was the last institution in the area to vaccinate its employees, and COVID testing as an employee is a mess to this day. Half-baked "conversations" and cookie-cutter online trainings about diversity and inclusion show that Cornell will continue to do nothing but the bare minimum for its employees.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The Benefits are great and the Reputation.
cons: NYP/Weill Cornell Lower Manhattan, 156 Williams Street 7th floor (Formerly New York Downtown) The department of medicine is dysfunctional, mangers do not know how to manage their staff, some of their staff are from New York Downtown, and they are rude and uneducated. The department of medicine hires uneducated temps, and the uneducated temps starts gossip and trouble among the new employees, why? Because the temps want the new employees jobs. It seems as though management likes the gossip too. It is suppose to be about the patients and not this cutthroat I want your job kind of thing.  Next to this department is OB/GYN and their management team seems to know how to run their staff and new employees. It all depends on who you work with, and which department. Weill Cornell should have gotten rid of all New York Downtown bad seeds. The Department of Medicine is unorganized!!! The management sucks, supervisors do not want to deal with hostile patients, supervisors do not know what they are doing. Wait, but get this, The Department of Medicine staff are Patient Coordinators, and GYN staff are Senior Patient Coordinators(both have same years of experience & degrees).  Medicine staff does more work than GYN, and get paid less. Basically, it is the same job function, but in this case The Department of Medicine’s Patient Coordinators are doing a lot more work at 156 Williams Street (Cheap Bastards). Whatever you do, do not work at 156 Williams Street, Department of Medicine. Weill Cornell itself is a good company work for, but not 156 Williams Street (formerly New York Downtown)

job_title: External Affairs in New York, NY
pros: The researchers, educators, and clinicians are all top-notch. The mission is inspiring. The brand name is well-known and respected. Who wouldn't want to work for an Ivy league, world-class medical school?
cons: Whatever salary you are offered from the start will likely not change, except 1-2 percent per year "merit" increases. There is rampant favoritism, politics, and gossip. There is an extremely high turnover in certain positions. Career ladders do not exist. There are different rules for people based on gender, age, race, etc..There is an overall expectation that employees should be going above and beyond every day and doing the job of 2-3 people. However, employees do not feel valued and thus are either 1. resentful, and/or 2. not inspired to increase productivity. Bringing new ideas to the table is discouraged. Differing opinions are highly discouraged.

job_title: Research Technician II in New York, NY
pros: If you need a paying job and don't expect much out of career advancement then you have found the right place to work. From the standpoint of a research technician, the research performed at the medical college is unprecedented. You will gain much experience from working in the academic laboratory setting. the people woring there ae fairly young. just out of college for a year or two. there are always symposiums that one may attend, and researchers are mostly professors, and hospital teaching staff. The medical college provides a great education, though challenging. If you are a researcher full-time, you pay approx $20 per office visit. no referral needed for specialists etc. dental is provided by 20th century (mediocre) and deductions for dental, and health avg approx 80/month. commute pretax deductions are offered.
cons: the amount of direction is inadequate to support the work that needs to be done. too much time is wasted on assumptions regarding tasks. many mistakes are made and covered up. the medical college needs to improve the support staff working in the facility. Animal husbandry department accidentally euthanized a wrong room full of mice. the work environment does not encourage one to develop or grow as an individual. rather slave and play as a grunt for the position employed. you may not have the freedom to determine when you leave work or come in and what needs to get done when. Miscommunication occurs often. politics are hugely at play in the work environment.

job_title: Senior Medical Secretary in New York, NY
pros: Fair compensation, great benefits. And all in all, they take great care of the patients-- NOT their employees. Other than that this place is pretty much horrible.
cons:
Poor management, lack of proper training, lack of proper review.

Working for this company was the worst decision of my professional career. They paint a pretty picture of a company that cares and puts their employees first. But in reality it is a lot of politics. I never received a formal review from this place, and was given a "lateral promotion" within two months of my starting because they were so "pleased" with my performance. Little did I know I would have twice the responsibility with out an increase in pay and ultimately be held accountable for the actions (or lack there of) of my coworkers. This place is a joke. Not only that, but when I attempted to file a formal complaint for the harassment I was subjected to from my manager, HR "discouraged" me as it would drastically affect my job.

This place is no good. I left a wonderful job for the "opportunities" this place was willing to give me. Please. Six months and I couldn't take another moment in that place.

Enter at your own risk.

job_title: Senior Medical Secretary in New York, NY
pros: Sick time ,vacation, tuition reimbursement , paid holidays
cons:
Men are paid far more than women. You are expected to learn over 70 physicians preferences and the rules for 10 different departments . If a slight error is made by someone else or if the physician feels that you are wrong the blame is brought down on you rational or not. You can ask leads for guidance as to why you were wrong,but they are unable to explain themselves and are quick to team up to try to get you fired. Room for growth is also nonexistent. 

If that's not bad enough half of the nurses are unresponsive and physicians are very rude to schedulers. Working at the call center is like a game of cat and mouse. If you have medical experience, please dont work there.You can do better than a 1-3% yearly raise.

job_title: Practice Supervisor in New York, NY
pros: Great team and newly renovated locations.
cons: pay rate is mediocre compared to its competition.

job_title: Physician in New York, NY
pros:
Collaborative work environment 
Quality peers
cons: Low transparency regarding institutional finance

review_title: Good faculty and resources, good science, poor administration
job_title: PhD Student in New York, NY
pros:
-Really dedicated faculty!
-Many top-notch labs to work in
-Great location, near MSKCC and Rockefeller
-Opportunity to go to many fantastic talks and lectures.
-Student clinic (SHS) is quite good; health insurance is adequate
-Students are eligible for subsidized housing nearby
-Publication and collaboration are encouraged
-Interesting courses
-Great extracurricular clubs and activities
-Good stipend
cons:
-No childcare
-Grad school administration can be difficult and unprofessional to work with
-There seems to be nowhere to turn if you have problems with housing, your PI, or professional/ethical concerns 
-The reimbursement procedure for conferences, work-related expenses, etc., can take 6 months-1 year
-The institution in general is bogged down with layers of departments and administrators; it is never clear who to go to with what question. A simple request for a form can take days to figure out!
-Postdocs are underpaid and under-served at Weill-Cornell

job_title: Outreach Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Great friendly atmosphere and caring people
cons: None. Love everything about Weill Cornell Medicine!

job_title: Medical Doctor in New York, NY
pros: Great colleagues to work with
cons: Happy to discuss in person

review_title: College needs to read its own employee mission statement
job_title: Operations Manager in New York, NY
pros: Benefits are OK, Vacation time good.
cons: It is a non-profit that makes a lot of money and is thus rife with inefficiencies verging on corruption and there is little motivation to change things as everybody is getting a cut.  It is important to note that individual departments could all be different but from my experience in Neurosurgery they are run like mini fiefdoms. Administrators making huge salaries while running the place like a dictatorship, the Chair employing an image consultant and the physicians expensing everything despite making millions while the staff are treated like children who cannot think for themselves.

job_title: Data Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Great stepping stone for those waiting to apply to medical school or for those who want to explore various careers available in medicine.
cons: JCTO management is just terrible. The office of clinical trials itself expanded past the infrastructure available so it's possible not to have an assigned desk for months. To make matter worse there are people who have to sit on boxes while sharing a desk with another person. The assistant director herself would asked the staff not to tell the physicians this... There is obvious a disconnect between JCTO and physicians  you work for. On one hand the physicians know the trials the best and will act in the patient's best interest, and you are there to essentially help the physicians help patients. JCTO management would say things out of left-field like, "we own you guys, not the physicians so you need to listen to us." This is absurd and the poor treatment of their employee is represented by the quick turn-around time.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros:
Basic research gets a lot of direction from the clinical side of the college. 
New York City has a lot of scientists to collaborate with.
Facilities are updated.
Lots of opportunities for networking, seminars, career advice.
cons:
Worst IT department I've ever come across in a university setting
Red tape covers everything.  Getting reimbursed for a conference is a Herculean task.
Basic science is not as respected as translational/clinical, so basic scientists can expect to be shoved down the priority ladder for a lot of things.
Lately, a lot of funding has left the university, making for tense times.
There's a lot of dead weight in the administrative chain.  Though there are very helpful shining stars that I've encountered, a good amount of admin staff are just incompetent and awful.

job_title: Computer Technician in New York, NY
pros:
- The institution strives to keep an even work-life balance and can be very flexible when necessary
- The salary is competitive given that it is an academic institution
- The above factors assists with workers' morale and facilitates a low attrition compared to other institutions. Due to the aforementioned factors, the work environment is not overly competitive and can sustain a supportive atmosphere
cons:
- The senior management tends to focus on what they believe is the right direction for the institution, without incorporating the consensus of the Weill community in decisions.
- Talent is at times overlooked because of nepotism and ageism, which stifles innovation and positive growth

job_title: Data Coordinator in New York, NY
pros:
Good opportunity for someone straight out of college who's looking for something before applying to grad/med school. No patient contact, so if you're looking for something similar to shadowing for a med school application, look elsewhere.

Good interaction with physicians, if you play your cards right you can really learn a lot here.

Benefits are ok. Medical/dental/vision, 403B, life insurance policy.
cons:
Management needs to get it together. Keep expanding to add people as upper management,  but not bothering to train properly. The whole office is badly in need of restructuring and a formal training program. Employee retention is also an issue - people come and work for a couple of months, then they leave.

Not a lot of room to move up unless you get into management, which can be hard.

job_title: Instructor in New York, NY
pros: Located in a great neighborhood of NYC. Some great scientists and OK facilities. It is a small plasce, which can be both advantageous and disadvantageous. On the plus side, you can meet nearly everyone. But on the negative side, you might not find a core facility or collaborator that you need on-site. Students are very good quality and many have drive to think independently and have prior experience.
cons: very small pond and if you don't enter with position you want, don't plan on being promoted and expect to be used to train MDs and get no credit. Worst is that for a top MD school, it isn't clear that administration gives a crap about student education and typically saves money by hiring third world MDs to teach and train students. Seminars can very poorly attended and you may be left wondering what holds the department together.

review_title: Relaxed, engaging place to work, but can be frustrating
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Depending on where you are in the organization, the work environment is pretty relaxed, and in general, you get to feel good about the fact that you're ultimately supporting science and medical care improvement. If waking up everyday and feeling like you're supporting a good cause is important to you, this is a great environment.
cons: Current institutional leadership doesn't yet have a clear focus, and it doesn't feel like we have solid plans in place to improve our standing as an institution. It's lead to some disarray at levels of the administration, and I get the feeling that everyone is, on a certain level, doing their own thing.  Also, HR is challenging to work with, and they have unrealistic salary views that are out of touch with the local market.

review_title: Rewarding and collaborative research that truly allows you to develop as a researcher
job_title: Research Technician in New York, NY
pros: What I like most about my work at WCMC is the collaborative yet independent nature of the research. I was able to work with various researchers in the WCMC system on very fascinating projects and learned many different lab skills. Additionally, I greatly appreciated the flexibility and independence my supervisors allowed me with my work.
cons: The HR is rather unresponsive and somewhat disorganized. Several individuals in my department waited weeks to see an adjustment in pay when awarded a raise. However, during the recruiting process, they are quite responsive.

review_title: Your experience will depend on the department you're working in
job_title: Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
The benefits are great.  As an exempt employee working here for over 3 years, I get 9 holidays, 22 vacation days, 12 sick days and 3 personal days.  Vacation and sick days carry over... up to a limit.

Tuition reimbursement - for employees, $5,000.  It's surprising to see that more employees don't take advantage of it.

good management/co-workers - if you are lucky.  In some departments, management is top notch.
cons:
Long walk - If you work at the medical college itself, your commute might be long (college is situated on York & 70th).
Some departments do not have a good working environment and lack culture.  
Favoritism in certain departments
Salary - low. Minimum annual raises.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Weill Cornell provides many different resources for their employees, particularly training workshops and online access to a variety of leadership and management courses. As with positions at many academic centers, another benefit are the hours, which typically do not exceed 40 hours per week.  The academic culture is one of great work/life balance, for administrative and support positions. No guilt for leaving on time, even for salaried employees.
cons: If you work in a small department there may be little opportunity for upward growth, without transfering into another department. In order to obtain the really high paying positions you typically need an MD or PhD.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Cornell is known for academic excellence, and there is great access to scientific facilities, as well as lectures by preeminent scientists and physicians.
cons: The compensation for scientific staff is so low (below janitorial pay in many cases) that it is necessary to subsidize my salary with odd jobs.  There is no opportunity for work-life balance, and females are actively discouraged from having children.  There is no administrative or HR support; in fact, there is more of an antagonistic, and very unprofessional, attitude towards scientific staff.

review_title: Roll of the Dice, depending on your department/division, particular lab
job_title: Data in New York, NY
pros: Some labs and departments are a great, laid back environment. Minimal dress code for some,  overall friendly, diverse coworkers. Offsite buildings are quiet environments, less stress than main campus. Somewhat inexpensive cafe and hospital cafeteria for those on the main campus. Brand new research building is top notch.
cons: Certain PI's or supervisors are extreme personalities, many managers and supervisors are brought on by PI's who they are friendly with etc., but they lack the practical and technical knowledge to do their job. Many ineffective communicators as well as poor communication bw department heads and staff. Some groups have tensions between staff that is ongoing--poor mediation and management of weak links. No transparency with regards to compensation, and bonuses only exist for favored Managers and supervisors.

review_title: With the new leadership, the institute has many improvements and has recruited many renown scientists.
job_title: Graduate Student Biomedical Sciences in New York, NY
pros:
A great place to do science with the tri-institutional collaborations. It provides lots of opportunities to interact with good scientists and start collaborations. 

Great neighborhood to live in. 

Very good daycare at affordable price. I appreciated that Dr. Laurie Glimcher helped to set up the daycare for the employees. She has brought many good changes and she genuinely cares about the employees.

Good benefits for graduate students.
cons: There was not a strong sense of community at least when I was there three years ago. More could have been done to earn loyalty from the employees. It's a big institute. Try to cut down the bureaucracy and focus on doing good science.

job_title: Product Trainer in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits and a excellent retirement savings plan.  Ability to roll over vacation days to the next year is amazing.  Stable environment,  I never felt like I was going to be let go even through our assigned business project was failing.
cons: Poor middle management and a clear culture of favoritism.  It seems like if you are friends with the right people you can just fly under the radar and work there forever as a low performer.  They would rather throw money at a problem and hire more people to do grunt work than simply fix the the business issue and promote from within.

job_title: Professor in New York, NY
pros: Generally speaking, it is a very good place to work but it is highly dependent on the group you work with and for. There is a high focus on patients and high quality work. They are very happy when you are successful and will usually try to help facilitate success.
cons: The infrastructure of the institution needs to be upgraded and specifically there needs to be more emphasis on communication and utilization of technology to adapt to the modern world.  They are very,very slowly moving towards fixing these problems however I could see that theses issues could still be problematic in 5 years.

job_title: Senior Administrative Secretary in New York, NY
pros: Good healthcare benefits. Also offer retire medical benefits and pension if you last that long.
cons: Very low pay. I myself gained 19% increase withing the five years I worked there.  However, as soon as my managers left the organization, they let me go.  Simple reason as they put it - "It's a budget thing".  No other division wanted to pick up on my salary.  They prefer Administrative Secretaries to earn no more than $42,000 per year if they can help it.  I earned approximately $52,000 and it was too much for them.

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New York, NY
pros: Ivy league institution, name recognition, brilliant scientists. I'm a postdoc in the Surgery department and I couldn't be happier with the scientific environment.
cons: Getting anything done paperwork-wise is a nightmare. Whether it's dealing with security to get access to your own lab or contacting someone about a reimbursement, it takes entirely too long to get anything done. IT (info technology) is the worst. It took them several months just to set up our new computers. IT has to do it, so there is no option to do anything yourself.

job_title: Senior Patient Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Friendly staff, excellent facility, up to date equipment, the building is always clean and doctors are very intelligent and friendly towards staff and patients, negotiable pay (was offered $21.25 and negotiated to $23.75)
cons: NO OVERTIME even if you stay late to finish work, administrator heads do not respect or have concern for workers, although the pay is great it is not proportional to how much work is required, not much opportunity for growth, average Intelligence is required for this job, but you do need to have a good memory and exceptional speaking and communication skills

review_title: Best hiring and job experience ever!
job_title: Patient Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: The salary is definitely competitive if you negotiate for what you want. I can't speak for other departments but my Managers and coworkers are really warm and friendly. They really take the time to train you thoroughly so you are fully equipped to do the job you are hired to do. Also all other department buildings are literally a block away from each other so anything you need is literally 5 mins away.
cons: I am a commuter and the walk from 68th and Lexington to York ace can be a bit tedious I. The morning.

job_title: Patient Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Great job, amazing doctors, very professional atmosphere.
cons: The managers and supervisors have no consideration for their employees. Taking time off is always an issue, family emergencies, sick days when you call out, they have no sympathy for you its a BIG DEAL. However, they take vacations constantly, leave early if they choose too, but want you to dedicate hours and hours at work.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros: Good benefits although slightly expensive medicare, especially for dependent. Housing at affordable pricing provided. Good career development and guidance provided by Postdoctoral Affair office of Weill Cornell itself.
cons:
No time off during probationary period (first 3 months), after that 14 calendar days per year, which is fair although employer didn't approve taking up this many holidays. 
Rough experience in my case because I got dismissed within my probationary period without valid reason. Luckily I got 3 months to find another job where my pay was continued.

job_title: Data Control Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Had opportunities to network with professionals from multiple nearby hospitals (Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Hospital for Special Surgery, and of course New York-Presbyterian), as well as within the WCMC community itself. Beautiful facilities and excellent support staff. Pay was not great, but the experience was valuable. Excellent benefits to see Cornell physicians.
cons: This was not a position that would lead to growth within the company; that being said, it was a great jumping off point for graduate school in health sciences and would have been a good start for medical school as well.

review_title: A great institution to work for!
job_title: Research Technician II in New York, NY
pros: Top of the line medical research, well funded, and state of the art facilities. Great collaboration with Sloan-Kettering and Rockefeller University. Great benefits and productive environment.
cons: Hard to change positions and grow into something bigger as it is a science academic environment. The departments are confusing and sometimes poses issues with getting things done regarding human resource issues.

job_title: Research Technician I in New York, NY
pros: Weill Cornell Medical College gives you essential laboratory experience for future endeavors in science. Working as an associate technician at Weill Cornell for a couple of years has afforded me many opportunities to pursue better positions in other places.
cons: It can be difficult to live in New York City with the salary that is offered as a research technician. Many coworkers have to live far away from work to manage their finances effectively.

review_title: Good Work Life Balance but Horrible Management/Unprofessional Work Environment in IT OPs
job_title: Business Analyst in New York, NY
pros: WCMC gives it's employees a great worklife balance, solid benefits and a great location in NYC for the IT Dept.
cons: Management is aloof, and lacks interpersonal skills, they do not take the time to get to know you. Secondly they are aware of employees in the department who are difficult to work with yet they do not give you any forewarning. In fact they allow people within the work environment to be disruptive, harassing fellow employees.

job_title: Nurse Practitioner in New York, NY
pros: great experience to learn medicine, see a lot of great patients
cons: My dept was very poorly managed, from the top down. Leadership was aloof.  There was high turnover so we were forced to cover for others all the time, so much that there was little time to get your own work done. Supervisors gossiped about my co-workers to me which i felt was extremely unprofessional and bred a culture of mistrust.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in New York, NY
pros: The company offers great benefits, including a generous tuition reembursement. Salaries are competitive, but yearly increases are standard.
cons: Each department is different. I find that Uptown offices offer more by way of cleaner enviroment, more professional employees etc. Downtown practices are not as supportive of its employees furthering education their education which is sad for a college institution.

review_title: Where it pays to do the bare minimum.
job_title: IT in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits, and the Institution as a whole is doing great things. There's also job security, as it's difficult to get fired.
cons: Academia Healthcare hasn't been known to be the most lucrative industry to be in. Within certain departments, senior management is too wrapped up with schmoozing and looking good, that they're neglecting the people who actually do the work. The strong people are getting all the work, and the slackers are all getting away with it as SR management is off in SAP land.

review_title: Great place to learn and network
job_title: Lab Technician in New York, NY
pros: You will always be surrounded by very intelligent and hard working people here. They are all very eager to share their enthusiasm about science and happy to take in interns and volunteers. You won't just scratch the surface, you will learn the ins and out of projects and become very involved with the tasks at hand. Great place to learn.
cons: Pay is not the best, as they are often struggling to get funding from the NIH. Many are let go for this reason and volunteers are used to replace the techs until more funding comes in.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Faculty is serious about caring for sick. Lots of nice people at staff level. Health benefits are good. Pay is competitive.
cons: It's not what you know, it's who you know. Promotions are given to cronies. Your boss can be an idiot who has friends in high places. Half the upper administration does nothing. It helps to be good-looking. So mistakes happen, and then someone gets fired. Not the boss.

review_title: From the best to the worst
job_title: Anonymous in New York, NY
pros: Weill Cornell Medical College (WCMC) was one of the best place to work for when I joined about 10 years ago. WCMC is still a prestigious organization and I enjoyed working there initially. WCMC benefits are average.
cons: Lot of favoritism from the management especially in IT department. IT senior management created hostile situation for its non favorable folks to leave. Every projects came with threats and negative words such as "Accountable", "Red Flag", "verbal and written warning". Most of the IT folks resigned within short period of time due to the threats and unprofessional manners from the management.

job_title: Laboratory Manager in New York, NY
pros: Cornell has a prestigious name attached to it and they feed off of that.
cons:
- low pay compared to other companies in the NYC area (ie. NYU Langone, MSKCC, Rockefeller)
- less vacation and sick leave compared to other companies
- Horrible work environment
-Work extra hours but do not get paid overtime
-expect to come in on weekends for free, or respond to emails and messages during late hours and over the weekend
-Rude co-workers 
-No room for growth
-People constantly leave or quit and have to deal with training new people all the time (every 6 months or less)

I can go on, but please take my advice and go work somewhere else if you have the opportunity.

review_title: Use this as a stepping stone
job_title: Senior Patient Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Have the name of your institution on your resume
cons: Management makes up their own rules hence the need to constantly contact HR to find out what the actual law and policies are.

job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Experience as an RA varies by department, but if you enjoy your mentor, the team you are working for, and the work you are contributing to, you will have a successful tenure in this position. I was also very supported in my desires to move on to graduate school and assistance with the application process.
cons: Like many positions in academia, you should not expect to be compensated for the work that you do that is outside of your regular hours. However, "compensation" for this work may come through value-added in learning experiences or adding to your CV.

review_title: Most amazing internship with the Marketing Director at Cornell Med Center!!!
job_title: Intern-Marketing, Surgery Department in New York, NY
pros: Great city, amazing and intelligent people, so many opportunities to grow and prosper in a college/medical environment. Great benefits for employees. Also part of the 6th best hospital in the country.
cons: As an intern, I was not paid. There are very few/no cons. Obviously, the environment can be a little stressful at times (being in the city and working at a hospital).

review_title: Job with a lot of opportunities for growth but it is physically demanding
job_title: Animal Care Technician in New York, NY
pros: All that you need is a high school diploma or GED and can get a decent paying job with clear channels to advancement.
cons: The politics of the job are more complicated than the work. You work with animals do there is the moral discussion. And it is a small department so small quarrels tend to be made bigger than necessary.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
- Great benefits (medical, dental, vision, tuition reimbursement, etc)
- Annual merit increase (only about 3% to 4%)
- Flexible with school and social schedule (certain departments)
- Looks good on your resume
cons:
- Physicians/NPs will go through leaps and bounds for certain patients, but not for all (aka "VIP" patients vs regular patients).
- Low Pay for the amount of work given in the department
- Asked for a raise and was told no. Received the same annual merit that every single WCM employee receives
- The commute from LI to NYC

review_title: Office Politics! Promotion based on if they like you and who you know (within the dept)
job_title: Senior Patient Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: excellent benefits, children tuition scholarship, tuition reimbursement
cons: no more then 40 sick hours (5.5 days) for the year or you run the risk of being written up, Not easy to get too.  Low pay. Would recommend to a friend just not my department!!

job_title: Patient Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Okay benefits and looks good on resume for future generally speaking
cons: Poor management college does not live up to its name employees gossip with supervisor about you no clear direction from supervisor co workers are not helpful as a new employee basically throw you in there without knowing if you are doing things correctly or not but when you make a mistake they are down your neck lots of "shade" with employees

job_title: Senior Clerk in Bronx, NY

job_title: ITS (IT) Analyst in New York, NY
pros: There are no cons to this place.  Well, maybe only the location of nyc if that could be a pro if you like the city.

I worked in IT and that just exacerbated the environment a 100 times as the IT department there is not too big and you have to deal with all departments.  IT Managers regularly curse you out using foul language, fiance personnel, purchasing and HR departmental people you need to work with in helping them to modify the system complain behind your back about you.  IT managers regularly have to set deadlines for functional specs tomorrow (because their managers force the deadline on them). Overall,if your born bred new yorker and are used to people telling you off to your face it might be for you.  thank-god I left for JnJ in NJ.  Much better cordial friendly people with chill-ax managers and very little stress in the IT dept there with managers who actually want to work with you to finish goals.  Also, they rip off you in terms of salary.  For example, my salary was $80k when I was working there but when I started working I noticed they only use a 80k base and pay for only 35 hours a week.  When I complained to Weil HR they told me your weil hr recruiter should have informed you that we only pay out 35 hour weeks.  What a scam, this non-profit is!

review_title: DO NOT WORK HERE  AS A PATIENT COORDINATOR! RUN FOR YOUR LIFE!
job_title: Patient Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: A paycheck, nice co-workers, nice equipment, personal days
cons: THIS PLACE IS HELL ON EARTH. This job started out decent, but turned into literal HELL. I've been working here for two years with NO RAISE! No financial appreciation. You are responsible for scheduling for 44+ providers, and expected to know all of their schedules/likes/dislikes.  You make one mistake, the doctor's secretaries are sending screenshots to your manager.  They only have to remember two doctor's schedules, meanwhile we have to learn 50! On top of that you are on the phone from the moment you begin till the moment you clock out. Back to back, NO relief.  Constant ringing in your ears. You are expected to answer up to 100 calls per day!  Often times with a 30 minute lunch break, not even the full hour. It is absolute MISERY. You are treated like just another number, not a human being. You constantly have to deal with angry patients, day in and day out, yelling at you for things you have no control over. We as patient coordinators have to take the brunt of EVERYTHING for our department, not the doctors. We have to put up with being yelled at, and complained to, and degraded, on a daily basis. And we have to just take it. There is no such thing as hanging up on a patient. This place disgusts me. Meanwhile upper management/doctors live their BEST life. There is only so much one human being can take! It has taken a huge toll on my mental health working here. I've even contemplated suicide working here because it's just too much.  I have no way out because I need the money.  If you are reading this, please avoid working as a patient coordinator. DON'T DO IT. The company as a whole is great, but working in a call center is not healthy for anyone. It is mentally draining and exhausting.
